p: Two distinct research groups from China have described the antidepressant effects of Perilla frutescens L. Britton essential oil in mice. Using the chronic unpredictable mild stress (CUMS), a well validated animal model of depression, these studies showed the effects of the essential oil in reversing behavioral, neurochemical, and immunological alterations induced by stress [ 42, 43]. The essential oil restored sucrose-preference in stressed mice, a behavior intrinsically related to anedonia, a core symptom of depression. In addition, the treatment with this oil also restored the increased immobility time in the FST and TST in CUMS mice, thus supporting a robust antidepressant-like action [ 42, 43]. Changes in 5-HT and BDNF levels might be based on the antidepressant actions.
